ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This class provides a different perspective on economic development focusing on social networks: the good and the bad. Later in the course, we also looked at how the economic transition can affect human biology. The extensive study of development papers was a really good way to understand the thinking that goes into writing for academia and coming up with studies and models.
I especially enjoyed learning about approaches to data collection and research, and how they should be considered when describing the results of research and possible conclusions.
I learned how to interpret and create economics models, and how to tackle economic questions from a micro-foundational perspective.

This seminar is definitely one of the best and most useful Economics classes at Yale. It is one of the only classes that truly exposes you to what economic research is like in the real world. This class taught me many skills including identifying frictions in an economy,  writing down an empirical model, testing the model by deriving predictions, estimating structured parameters, addressing counterfactuals explanations and testing mechanisms. If you are interested in pursuing higher degrees in economics, development or social science in general, this is the perfect class for you.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The strength of the course is the seminar style which allows for greater interaction between the students and professor. Another strength is the clear passion that the professor has for the topic.

Professor Munshi is one of the most important assets at Yale's economics department. He constantly tried to engage his students with the material despite how isolating Zoom sessions can be. The class was very structured, and the syllabus was very clear. The class covered a wide range of topics in development economics but the professor always made sure that we understand the general connection and institution. Although some of the models were a bit technical for other economics classes at Yale, he always broke it down to make it very easy for the students. The best part of the class was student presentations because we got to research a topic and present it to the class. This was a very good way to test/reflect on our general understanding of the material and how we approach research papers in economics.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Professor Munshi is one of the most important assets at Yale's economics department. He constantly tried to engage his students with the material despite how isolating Zoom sessions can be. The class was very structured, and the syllabus was very clear. The class covered a wide range of topics in development economics but the professor always made sure that we understand the general connection and institution. Although some of the models were a bit technical for other economics classes at Yale, he always broke it down to make it very easy for the students. The best part of the class was student presentations because we got to research a topic and present it to the class. This was a very good way to test/reflect on our general understanding of the material and how we approach research papers in economics.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Absolutely. This class is easily in my top 3 classes I've taken at Yale. More than just learning concepts and reading papers, this class really changes your perspective on economics. The material is rather difficult (especially at the beginning of the semester) but Prof Munshi is very understanding and the studies we looked at are super interesting. If you're truly interested in econ, I think this is a class you absolutely should take sometime in your 4 years

I would very much recommend this course to other students who are interested in economic theory as it relates to development economics, and to students who want to further their understanding of model creation and formulating research.

Definitely! If you are interested in economic research and/or development, this is the PERFECT class for you. The class cover some of the most important and interesting topics in development. The class is also taught by one of the most prominent contributors to the economics fields. I took many seminars (especially on development) at Yale, but Professor Munshi's seminar was the most engaging. He always try to challenge his students and bring new ways of thinking about development economic. I personally loved this class, especially its unique combinations of research papers and technical models.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
